review:
Классический квест, прямиком с 80-х. В своё время игра отлично игралась, хотя и не была популярна. Сюжет и интересное приключение не отпускали пока не пройдёшь игру до конца. Вам предстояло поучаствовать в одном из самых знаменательных событий в американской истории. А именно в эпоху Золотой Лихорадки.
Однако если рассуждать объективным и быть честным, то порекомендовать игру не могу. Слишком уж морально устарела. И не только визуально. В плане геймплея игра не для широкой аудитории. Управление для неискушённого игрока может показаться трудным, а то и вовсе непонятным. А ещё нужно набраться терпения, ибо главный герой двигается крайне медленно. А локаций пересечь предстоит более чем много.
В общем, игра хорошая, была в своё время. Сейчас же она может отпугнуть одним только визуальным рядом, не то, что геймплеем. Если же всё-таки хотите приобщиться к классике, то рекомендую ознакомиться с ремейком этой игры. Зайдите на страницу разработчика, там его найдёте. Сам я не играл в него, в планах заценить. Но выглядит вполне неплохо. Визуал так уж точно не отпугнёт, как минимум:-)

author: {'steamid': '76561198452915382', 'num_games_owned': 55, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 191, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 191, 'last_played': 1704102403}
review:
Gold Rush! Classic transporta a los jugadores de vuelta a la emocionante época de 1849, cuando se descubrió oro en California. Con tres rutas diferentes, el juego sigue el viaje de Jerrod Wilson desde Nueva York hasta California. La estética única y el diseño de arte hacen que la experiencia se sienta auténtica en el siglo XIX.

El juego ofrece tres rutas distintas, cada una llena de desafíos históricos. Ya sea cruzando las Grandes Llanuras, atravesando el Istmo de Panamá o rodeando el Cabo de Hornos, cada elección tiene sus propios obstáculos. Llegar a Sutter's Fort es solo la mitad de la aventura, ya que muchos rompecabezas adicionales aguardan antes de alcanzar los objetivos en California.

Las reseñas destacan aspectos positivos como la ambientación única, la nostalgia que evoca y la inclusión de elementos extra, como mapas históricos y dibujos conceptuales originales. Algunos jugadores señalan una curva de aprendizaje debido a eventos inesperados, pero encuentran el juego divertido una vez que se comprenden las mecánicas.

En resumen, Gold Rush! Classic parece ser una opción recomendada para aquellos que buscan una experiencia nostálgica y disfrutan de juegos con una ambientación histórica única. Aunque puede no cumplir con las expectativas modernas en algunos aspectos, su encanto clásico y desafíos estratégicos lo hacen valioso para quienes aprecian los juegos de la década de 1980.

author: {'steamid': '76561198111976476', 'num_games_owned': 469, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 404, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 404, 'last_played': 1703101608}
review:
Released in 1988, Gold Rush is a shining example of classic adventure gaming.
The attention to historical detail is commendable, immersing the player in the hardships and triumphs of those seeking fortune in the 19th century.

The pixel art is charming and the carefully designed landscapes, towns, and characters come together to create an atmosphere that is both captivating and authentic. The soundtrack, though simple, complements the experience beautifully, enhancing the sense of adventure and discovery.

One of the standout features of "Gold Rush" is its emphasis on decision-making and consequences. Choices you make as Jerrod have a ripple effect on the story, making each playthrough feel unique and personal. The non-linear narrative encourages exploration and experimentation, allowing players to uncover different facets of the story with each playthrough.

That being said, the game is difficult. You can die in many unexpected and sudden ways (save often!) and time is of essence. If you haven't completed some steps by a certain time, you won't be able to get back to them. Also, if you have missed an item in the start, you might find yourself unable to proceed during later stages of the game. The text parser adds to the adventure feeling. However, the trial and error can be frustrating, especially since there are timed events.

If you embark on this adventure with the awareness that the game is indeed difficult and is not a modern point and click adventure, you'll discover a virtual gold mine of entertainment. So, grab your virtual pickaxe and dive in – the gold is there for those willing to undertake the challenge.

It's not perfect and has some of the same problems as other old adventure games, like locking yourself by missing early items or random deaths you can't avoid. But it's a very unique setting and there are multiple ways to get through the game. And even though some of the puzzle solutions are obscure, they at least follow a line of logic and the solutions make sense.

If you're not already a fan of these types of games then you can probably pass on this; it's not going to do anything to win you over. But for those people that already enjoy these kinds of games this is definitely worth picking up!

author: {'steamid': '76561199215971525', 'num_games_owned': 170, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 712, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 712, 'last_played': 1688325938}
review:
Having never spent any time on the many MS-DOS games around the 80's and early 90's on account of having been born a good decade or so too late to truly enjoy the older titles of gaming, I made sure to at least pay homage to one of the classics made by none other than the legendary studio that took hold of the text adventures of old and pioneered them into a new, more modern, form that was the graphics adventure, where being able to visually see the action unfold introduced a whole new layer of storytelling previously not seen up until the start of the 80's! (And only growing from there, with the likes of Mystery House serving as a stepping stone to the nostalgic games that all lovers of adventure and fantasy grew fond of over the many years!)

Of course, here we're discussing one of their later entries into what one might call the 'EGA 16-colour' era of adventure games Sierra here, as Gold Rush! was quite the bold entry as a one-off adventure covering what the massive rush towards California and their untold amounts of gold over in Coloma by telling the epic tale (one of many works of fiction inspired by various stories, mixed in truth alongside some slightly exaggerated claims!) of Jerrod Wilson, our main protagonist for this title, who we start off with in Brooklyn over in New York where it is mere minutes until the declaration for California's gold is announced.

The rest, as they say, is history.

Now to actually touch upon the gameplay itself here, the player can engage with their environment by means of moving around with the directional buttons or numerical pad to get to where they need to whilst typing in various commands at the bottom in order to interact with the various items and people within said area, whether it be to look at something to get a further examination or a general outlook of the area, to speak to somebody for general converse or to inquire about specific things relevant to their job or profession to make progress with Jerrod's quest, that or to use the many items Jerrod will collect throughout his quest to California that will determine whether he will survive the event or succumb to his demise in one of several dozen ways!

Seeing as this is an old game from the MS-DOS days though, it is to be expected that Gold Rush! is a title that whose gameplay will be largely unfamiliar to younger, more casual gamers of today and perhaps even be off-putting to them despite being intrigued by the crisp and colourful pixelized graphics that were drawn and crafted so expertly back over 30 years ago.

The reason why I mention this is two-fold, the first problem being a general lack of direction on where to go to accomplish one's objective as, despite the game sometimes giving you good hints on where to get something done, it can still be relatively vague as I had to refer to a guide on at least three separate occasions (once on the way to California and twice more once having arrived there) after having tried seemingly everything to make reasonable progress into the story.

The other reason is a more problematic one, which largely comes down to the choice of words that this game will accept for getting a command put through by the player, by which I mean Gold Rush!'s selection of words that it will allow for you to process a specific action (be it requesting something, asking about a particular event or person or even how to do a more specific action outside of just picking up or dropping something) can be particularly tricky as the limited vocabulary accepted by what the developers would expect players to use at the time the game was made can often make trying to put in a specific action for Jerrod to do a chore by means of guesswork as it were.

Still, I will commend Gold Rush! for having three entirely unique and different routes for getting Jerrod from New York all the way over to California as, alongside the expected method of travelling by Stage Coach that is always available as it doesn't leave without you and costs as much as the amount of money Jerrod has in his bank account which doesn't change regardless of items bought, the other two more fancy routes involve travelling by boat, one of which takes the player across Cape Horn whilst the other has them traversing through the Panamian Jungle to reach California quicker, as they all have their own fun and unique challenges to offer the player as, worst-case scenario, one route being impossible to complete without looking up a guide does not necessarily mean the end of the game with the two others being available if the player makes the right financial choices prior to the announcement for California's gold.

One serious issue I do have to bring up though, doing my best to avoid spoilers here, is towards the last third of the game where you reach Coloma and must retrieve several crucial items hidden away in a building that are key to navigating the last area of the game to meet your brother, as you are meant to distract the renter of a hotel room by means of getting a letter from the receptionist to then get inside and make your way towards the room you need to get into, however I could not get him to give me the letter, no matter which way I typed (issues have been reported that you can't type in numbers for this version, however it seems the game will recognize a 'twenty three' in place of '23') by various means of trial and error, and could not proceed in the intended manner, instead having to resort to a less 'ideal' method of break and entry, which gets the job done however cost me points (some actions in this game will result in you losing score instead of gaining, and this has no limit unlike the positive scoring actions!) which was not the greatest impression when so near the end of the game.

However seeing how it is going for a relatively cheap price as of the writing of this review here at £2.09, noting that it used to be far more expensive than before, I would recommend this game to those who never had the chance of exploring the originals and are willing to exercise some patience with the old gameplay mechanics expected to be seen back in the older days of gaming alongside that aforementioned bug preventing a perfect score of 255, (250 if the Panama route was not taken) as this is not an easy game to get into for the casual gamers of today despite it's intriguing premise and lovely 16-bit world capturing the essence of the American gold rush of 1849.

TLDR Version:

• Excellently-told tale focusing on the iconic California Gold Rush of 1849 that does a great job at capturing the fun moments as well as the harsh realities of travelling the untamed lands of America (+)
• Gold Rush! captures the mid-19th century essence of the United States with detailed 16-bit graphics that are well-crafted and look amazing for a game coming from the late 80's (+)
• Gameplay is more dynamic than seen in most of Sierra's other titles as there are multiple routes to take to California that each present their own unique challenges (+)
• The game offers many puzzles, plenty of them having a second solution that offers less points but is the more obvious and direct of the two, alongside offering plenty of history surrounding the gold rush (+)

• Gold Rush!'s gameplay can be seen as quite outdated and would limit the amount of gamers in today's video game scene that would truly enjoy it, even if the story intrigued them (-)
• Some puzzles are quite vague and require a lot of trial-by-error or looking up a guide as sometimes it is not made clear how to best approach it (-)
• A bug specific to this port unfortunately prevents a perfect score as, late into the game, the ideal solution to a puzzle is not possible due to a specific action needed not going through (-)
• Trying to find the right word that the game will accept for an action by the player may prove too frustrating for those used to more modern adventure games that rely on the 'point-and-click' method (-)

review:
Yet another surprise classic game that I didn’t expect to enjoy. I don’t have nostalgia for Gold Rush like I do with The Oregon Trail, but the two games share a similar vibe. 

This game is more of an adventure game compared to the decision making survival style of Oregon Trail. Like other entries in the genre, Gold Rush requires a ton of save scumming and guide usage to see the full experience. Although sometimes frustrating, the vibes are strong enough that it’s still fun to play. There’s also some replayability here with multiple routes to reach your destination offered, each with some unique events.

If you enjoy old adventure games, try Gold Rush. I can’t recommend the remake though.

review:
Сколько бы ни смеялись над различными симуляторами тракториста или погрузчика, стоит признать, что жанр этот показал себя вполне достойно и нашёл свою аудиторию. Рутинная вроде бы работа, от которой, наоборот, хочется отдохнуть, но подобные игры внезапно оказались довольно популярными. Правда, в случае с симуляторами фермера или автомеханика экзотики мало: даже городской житель примерно представляет, каким образом кусок мяса с ломтём хлеба попадают к нему на стол, а автомобилем так или иначе пользуется каждый и в общих чертах понимает, что там тарахтит под капотом. Но есть проекты, освещающие и заметно более узкие области. Один из подобных — Gold Rush: The Game, представляющая собой симулятор золотодобытчика.
Несмотря на специфичность и редкость рабочей специальности золотодобытчика, интерес к этой профессии остаётся высоким со времён Джека Лондона (Jack London). Конечно, рядовой обыватель вряд ли отправится в неизведанные дали для того, чтобы самостоятельно заняться добычей золота, но вот на досуге почитать о приключениях Смока Беллью или посмотреть очередную познавательную передачу о золотых приисках — всегда пожалуйста. Одна из таких телепрограмм — реалити-шоу «Золотая лихорадка», которая идёт в эфире канала Discovery Channel с 2010-го года и по сей день обладает довольно высокими показателями рейтинга. Как вы уже, наверное, догадались, Gold Rush: The Game создана именно на основе этой самой телепередачи.
Как и в сериале, в игре главный герой отправляется ловить удачу за хвост, держа путь в небольшой городок, вокруг которого расположились несколько золотоносных приисков. В кармане пара сотен долларов, фонарик и ключи от старенького пикапа, а также лопата (не удивляйтесь — инвентарь здесь не предусмотрен в принципе, так что где ещё эту лопату хранить?). Остальное придётся добывать собственными руками.
В городе, несмотря на захолустный вид, есть всё необходимое для золотоискателя: банк, в котором можно получить кредит на развитие бизнеса, арендовать или купить участок, а также продать готовые золотые слитки; магазины техники и оборудования; наконец, заправка и кузнец. На самом деле, можно прямиком отправиться на прииск, предварительно арендовав участок, — минимум необходимого для работы (кроме всё той же лопаты, она всегда при вас) можно будет найти прямо на месте. Но начинать подобным образом, намывая буквально отдельные песчинки вручную, конечно, глупо.
С помощью довольно схематичного руководства разработчики объясняют, что возможные способы добычи золота делятся на три группы, первая из которых полностью ручная, а оставшиеся автоматизированы с помощью применения различных машин и оборудования. Для самых маленьких — поэтапные пояснения, вплоть до указаний, что и где купить, сопровождаемые видеороликом непосредственного процесса добычи. Но в принципе до всего можно додуматься и самостоятельно, особенно если вы смотрели тот самый сериал, — происходящее в игре выглядит вполне логично и реалистично.

review:
Przepis na bigos
Składniki: / 4 porcje
500 g mięsa wieprzowego (np. karkówki)
200 g kiełbasy
1 cebula
2 łyżki oleju roślinnego
3 szklanki bulionu lub wody
30 g suszonych borowików
2 łyżki powideł śliwkowych lub kilka suszonych śliwek
1 jabłko (np. reneta lub antonówka) - opcjonalnie
1 kg kiszonej kapusty
1 łyżka koncentratu pomidorowego
1 łyżka mąki
1 łyżka masła
Przygotowanie:
Mięso pokroić w kostkę. Cebulę pokroić w kosteczkę i zeszklić na oleju w dużym garnku. Dodać mięso i dokładnie je obsmażyć.
Wlać 2 szklanki gorącego bulionu lub wody z solą i pieprzem, zagotować. Następnie dodać połamane suszone grzyby, przykryć, zmniejszyć ogień i gotować przez ok. 45 minut.
Dodać listek laurowy, ziela angielskie, kminek, majeranek, powidła śliwkowe lub posiekane śliwki, obrane i pokrojone w kosteczkę obrane jabłko i wymieszać.
Dodać odciśniętą kiszoną kapustę oraz wlać szklankę wody, wymieszać. Przykryć i gotować przez ok. 15 minut.
Kiełbasę obrać ze skóry, pokroić w kostkę i podsmażyć na patelni. Dodać do kapusty i gotować przez ok. 30 minut. Pod koniec dodać koncentrat pomidorowy.
Mąkę podsmażyć na suchej patelni, gdy zacznie brązowieć dodać łyżkę masła i mieszać aż masło się rozpuści.
Trzymając patelnię na ogniu dodać stopniowo kilka łyżek kapusty cały czas mieszając. Przełożyć zawartość patelni z powrotem do garnka, wymieszać i zagotować.
Wskazówki:
Jeśli używamy kiełbasy wiejskiej, kruchej, to nie musimy jej wcześniej podsmażać.

review:
[i]Gold Rush Classic[/i] is for collecting, but not for playing, except for the nostalgia of it.  When it was released, simple animated details like pedestrians going by on the street were amazing.  The fact that our character plodded around painfully slowly just gave you more time to appreciate it.  And the command line accepted your instructions -- with a little feeling around to find out what verbs the parser liked.  None of these things are exciting anymore.

Given that all the selling points of the game have become obsolete, while the annoyances have only become more prominent with time, I can only recommend GRC to those who want it as a piece of memorabilia.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961358815', 'num_games_owned': 2315, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 110, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 110, 'last_played': 1641052755}
review:
That's a really old school text adventure with a pixelated graphics. It might have been fun if not for several annoying things about it:

* Character introduction - the one you can observe just before starting playing - lacks in a lot of way. You just learn that you are looking for adventure and than you are thrown in a middle of a city and have no idea what to do hear - what's the goal, why you're here, what you can do. There are some places you can learn more about yourself, but considering that you are not an amnesiac, or the protagonist wasn't transported to some other world/time, but is just a normal citizen, takes a lot from roleplaying aspect here.
* This is a text adventure with simple graphics. Besides just moving around using arrows, you must type the commands to interact with the environment. But the actual help here is very brief. There isn't even at general least a list of commands or anything about how to actually interact with objects. You will be guessing a lot which of the verbs actually work, and which will be ignored by the game engine, how to talk to other people, how to look through the stuff around you etc.
* The graphics is very poor (but that's kinda understandable), and the sound is earhurting - so it's really good you cannot actually play it higher res, and you can turn the sounds off. Additionally there is a lot of places on your screen where your character will move behind a wall or other obstacle, and you won't see anything. That's really annoying.

I didn't like it at all - comparing with other old classics like Leisure Suit Larry, King's Quest, Space Quest etc - this one is really nothing to talk about. I cannot recommend it at all - for me it was just a waste of time (good thing I only wasted only about 2h with it).

For the time, along other known games of Sierra, it was very advanced, since allmost all the adventure games were text adventures only, without a graphic interface. We can interact with the game using a 'parser' to wrote commands, as in all text adventure games at the time, though.
In my opinion, this game scores 7/10.
Note: You can improve the sound if you modify 'tandy=auto' to 'tandy=on' on the DOSBox config file.

author: {'steamid': '76561198132503739', 'num_games_owned': 601, 'num_reviews': 548, 'playtime_forever': 345, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 345, 'last_played': 1585207603}
review:
[b]My playtime:[/b] 5.7h (based on steam)
[b]Developer Response:[/b] Yes (~1 month).

[h1]Intro[/h1]
Gold Rush! Classic is a text based adventure game where you travel to California in search of gold. You can move with arrow keys and do action by typing on the textbox below the screen.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
The game uses 2D sprite graphics. I think the graphics are still pretty good for an old game. The game is fixed in 800x600 resolution though. Also, the menu in the game is pretty much limited; it's only in black and white where you can navigate through a menu bar above your screen. The help option is also quite simple since it just replaces the screen with a bunch of text.

[h1]Story[/h1]
The game doesn't really cover much story in the beginning. It only says that you're Jerrod Wilson, someone who's stuck in a company and long for an adventure. You'll uncover more story as you progress and the story will move to become searching your long lost brother and finding gold in California. To be honest, there isn't much in the story but your adventure will be recorded thoroughly as you go so i'm sure you'll enjoy it if you're an avid reader. 

[h1]The game[/h1]
The game will start right after you start the game; there won't be a main menu at all and you can reload your save or tinker with the menu by pressing escape button. To be honest, i didn't know what to do even after i control my character. I also had a problem with walking since the walking system is very unusual; you just need to press an arrow button to go to a direction once and the character will automatically move to that direction until you change direction or press the same button again.

You'll need to explore the whole area in order to understand what you can do in the current area. However, it doesn't mean that you just need to walk in every area. You also need to inspect everything by typing in the textbox below the screen. There are 3 commands available in the help button: t for talking, l for looking, and g for getting items. I thought these are the only commands available in the game so i got stuck again. I ended up watching a [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nnJ1oufyU-E&t=2676s]youtube video[/url] just to find out that you can actually use other actions to progress the game. You'll actually need to use your imagination and brain for this since while most commands are obvious or hinted, there are some commands that are really vague. One example is somewhere in a desert [spoiler](when you're going on land)[/spoiler] where you only can find a barrel. It is not specified what the barrel contains even after you inspect it so you have to guess what is inside.

The game not only offers a lot of areas and possibilities to explore, but it also introduces a different way to get to your destination. While you'll still aiming to go to California, there are 3 routes with different adventure that you can take. Most of these adventures are being told through a bunch of text with short visual of your route and its progress but there are also some point in those adventures where you can move and take action to decide your fate.

Speaking of fate, yes, you can die. You can die because of silly stuffs like getting run over by a horse and you can also die because of RNG not in your favor. To be honest, i kinda like the first one very much but i don't really feel the same for the second one. There is also this place [spoiler](the gold cave)[/spoiler] where you can die because you're not walking in the right pixel that frustated me a lot because the control isn't really that friendly to make such a precise movement.

Despite all that, i think the game is quite enjoyable if you know what to do. I enjoyed the game more right after i followed a [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=694233630]walkthrough[/url] to finish the game. I also just noticed that there is actually a manual pdf in the game files that help you to play the game. I wished i had read it before i played to know the game better. Anyway, the only thing that i don't really like is how you need to wait for minutes just to get the next event to trigger.

Lastly, you can change the speed in the game. You can change it from 'slowest' to 'fastest' to make it easier. I didn't notice the speed up in some places though, like the first area.

Actually, the game itself can be finished in 1.5 hour if you know what to do, but you can expand it by taking different routes and explore  the area (and doing trial and error to get through everything) yourself.

Pros:
- 3 different routes with different adventures
- Need to guess the right commands
- Trial and error to explore the whole area

Cons:
- RNG deaths
- Confusing controls and no instructions
- You need to read the manual first to understand the game

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
This is a text based adventure game where you need to guess what action you can take and explore the whole area.

[h1]Should you buy this game?[/h1]
[b]Yes.[/b]
[i]To be honest, i'm not sure if i should recommend this game or not. This game is good for nostalgia, but i doubt that people who never play the game will enjoy this a lot. I guess you can buy this game on discount if you want to have some nostalgia.[/i]

While Gold Rush! gets off to a promising start, thanks to its impressive visuals for an AGI adventure and ability to educate players about the perilous journey to California during the mid-19th century, it eventually becomes apparent that this game shares the same pitfalls as many other Sierra adventures in that there are several instances of unforgiving puzzles and dead-ends; worse, the game also has random events that you have no way of avoiding except for restarting the game and hoping for the best next time. So, a bit like a rogue-like to some degree, except nowhere near as much fun.

(I've placed the following disclaimer when reviewing Sierra games before and I'll say it again: before I get burned at the stake by the Sierra fans, I'm trying to judge this game on its own merits, playing it today in 2019. review:
[h1][b]Gold Rush! Classic[/b][/h1]
Um grande clássico de 1988, um jogo difícil que te dá uma certa sensação de liberdade.

[h1]Mecânica, Jogabilidade e História[/h1]
[b]Mecânica: 8/10[/b]
A mecânica do jogo é bem arcaica, porém falamos de um jogo de 1988, portanto não podemos compará-lo com os de hoje em dia, diferente dos point and click atuais, você move o personagem através das setas do teclado, e qualquer ação do jogo deve ser digitada com o verbo correto e aprovado pelo jogo, isso é legal pois te dá uma certa sensação de liberdade, apesar de não tê-la. 
[b]Jogabilidade: 8/10[/b]
A jogabilidade é um problema, o jogo não te dá uma explicação do que fazer, você tem uma ideia geral, por um lado gosto de jogos assim, antigamente jogávamos sem detonados ou sem muita explicação nos jogos e nos divertíamos muito, portanto não importo de ter que procurar o que tenho que fazer no jogo, o problema é que dependendo do que você fizer (ou deixar de fazer) você pode chegar em um beco sem saída, e então pode esquecer pois não irá terminar o jogo (Algo que sempre gostei em jogos antigos, tentativa e erro, becos sem saídas, jogos de aventura em texto).
[b]História: 9/10[/b]
Não conhecia a história do ouro na Califórnia de 1849, mas após jogar o jogo e ler algumas análises que diziam que a história era precisa, decidi pesquisar e posso dizer que realmente o jogo é preciso, parabéns para os desenvolvedores. O jogo também te dá três rotas diferentes para progredir no jogo.

[h1]Considerações finais[/h1]
Um jogo antigo com mecânicas, gráficos, jogabilidade arcaicos, portanto não agradaria um público mais novo, você não terá muita ideia do que fazer e terá que descobrir como progredir, e acredite isso vai levar um tempo, mas o jogo é ótimo, Gold Rush dá uma certa nostalgia, um excelente jogo para relembrar o passado e para se divertir.

[b]Nota Final: [u]8,3/10[/u][/b]

review:
I'm a fan of old-school adventure games, but this is a game which I don't feel has aged very well. In particular, it suffers from a lot of the problems Sierra games were notorious for (obscure puzzles, random deaths, becoming stuck when missing items early in the game, etc).

Pros:
- Charming graphics style which does a surprisingly good job representing 19th century America.
- Many puzzles have multiple different solutions.
- Covers a specific historical time period, which is a rare focus for adventure games, especially at that time.

Cons:
- For some interactions you need to wrestle with the text parser to figure out what wording it expects.
- You can get stuck late in the game if you miss a couple of items near the start of the game.
- Puzzle difficulty feels very imbalanced. When they're not overly simple, they're very obscure or extremely finicky.
- There is very little story in the game.
- A couple of screens feature a random element which will kill you without any warning.

author: {'steamid': '76561198096019371', 'num_games_owned': 336, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 941, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 886, 'last_played': 1561701848}
review:
A real Sierra Classic. Never played it back then, but it features everything that made Sierra adventures so much fun to play.
- great locations/atmosphere -> check
- great storytelling -> check
- great puzzles -> check
- historical/educational background -> check
- many dead ends -> check
- multiple paths to complete the game -> nice... check
- funny -> well it has its moments but the story is not about gags and humor.

However this adventure might not appeal to everyone. Especially younger audiences that are not used to this kind of game mechanics (text parser, dead ends, no hint system, lots of trial and error) might find it hard to enjoy this game. You can get stuck a lot. Be patient and you will be rewarded or just use a walkthrough, but you will miss out a great part of the experience that made those games so great.

This is a little gem from the golden era of adventures. 

For classic adventures fans it's worth more than the regular price. For adventure game fans in general, get in on sale.

review:
Steam Awards made me do this .. :-)
Might as well do it then .. Let's talk Gold Rush! for a minute..

Had me a 80286 back in the days. Played a bunch of the Sierra Online classics on it!
Really enjoyed them too! In particular before it went all point-and-click.
You'd get stuck in one of these games and there was no internet you could ask for help..
You had to talk to actual human beings when you got seriously stuck..

Managed to complete a bunch of the games.. 
But not Gold Rush! .. 
As magical as it was having to type commands to interact with the games as frustrating it could be when the game just didn't understand you!
And that's what happened to me with Gold Rush! 

I knew what to do .. but the game would not cooperate ..

At this point do feel free to giggle at the fact that this can be interpreted as I didn't have any friends to ask.

Anyway .. I didn't strike gold back then.

And I must admit I still haven't.. 

But it's still a Sierra Online classic that so belongs in my (ever growing..) Steam library!

Whether it belongs in yours I wont attempt to answer.

Disclaimer: 
The hours played ( 4.8 at the time of writing this review ) was mainly to collect the trading cards .. I mean *cough* .. I could've completed it in this time for sure .. *cough*

Mini-guide: if you hear "Sierra" and think of mountains rather than epic questing, check out the mini-guide below my review. 

I never played Gold Rush back in the day but I'm fairly certain it would have taken me a bit longer than 5 hours to complete when I was a kid. There was no internet, no Windows, no mouse interface. Joysticks optional. I estimate about 5 months, and probably only after getting hold of some walkthrough, 

If you've never played one of the original Sierra games, you may find Gold Rush incredibly frustrating but take the time to learn the basics (see below) and you will fall in love with the depth and humour of these deceptively simple looking adventures.

Gold Rush is a classic adventure game, running beautifully via dosbox. There is no mouse interface whatsoever, keyboard (or joystick) only. I had so much fun with this. I recommend it without hesitation to anyone who remembers using DOS, and encourage anyone who doesn't but who loves adventures and puzzles to to give it a go.

[b]How to play (a mini-guide):[/b]

You control a sprite called Jerrod Wilson. He moves around his environment which is split into a grid of "rooms", each of which is the size of an olden-days computer monitor screen. If he goes to the very left of the screen, that moves him into the next "room". He can enter doors and buildings in one "room" which take him to another.

Jerrod has a story but you don't learn the details up front. You have to work it out by exploring, and examining items and reading various material. The story matters. The details and dialogues are important.

[u]Before you begin:[/u] Grab a pen and paper. If you want a map to help navigate, you need to draw it yourself. Write anything down that might be important, or to remind yourself of something later. Gold Rush is actually pretty light on these requirements. The map areas are small, and there is only one important number to remember - but there are lots of clues that might not seem obvious at first

[u]Movement:[/u] arrow keys or numpad. You can even move diagonally, unless you're playing on my laptop, which doesn't have a numpad, in which case, get off my laptop.

[u]Interaction:[/u] keyboard only. Very little automatic interaction. I think most unlocked doors will automatically open when you approach them but that's it. Typing involves either a command (eg "look" to get a textual decription of the area) or a verb/noun combination (eg "look man" to look at a man).

[u]Common verbs:[/u] look (abbreviated to "l"), look at, look in, look on, look under, talk, get ("g"), put, push, pull, open, close. Examples: open letter, look under rug, get mule.

Spelling matters! F3 repeats the last command. LOOK AT everything. Everything you can see will have an accompanying description. It's going to be hard to see some things.

Type HELP in game, or hit F1 to see the in-game help text.

[u]Number one rule:[/u] Save your game, save, save, save and then save again just to be sure. You will die a lot. F5 saves your game, F7 loads your saved game ("restore"), F9 restarts. If you're not sure if something was meant to happen or not, just F7. Use every save slot.

The game is brutal. You have 14 minutes at the beginning of the game to get things sorted before prices explode and you need to restart. If you don't have the right syntax you potentially miss something important. A lot of things won't seem intuitive if you haven't played these kinds of games before. Almost finished but you forgot to grab something at the beginning? You can't go back, so you have to start over.

You will be very tempted to use a walkthrough. They are just so accessible now. My suggestion is, play an area (like Brooklyn) through on your own, and before you leave, check to make sure you did everything you were supposed to. That's how I played because I wasn't in the mood to tear my hair out in clumps.

There are often multiple ways to solve a problem. One choice is not necessarily better than another.

Hope you love this experience.

I do recommend getting it while it's on sale for 59 cents. Not because it's not a good game (it's fine), but rather because as old as it is $6 does seem a tad steep (which I suspect they know). It's at the point now where you can say "it's an aqcuired taste I suppose" about games this old and that would feel about right.

review:
INTRODUCTION:
Gold Rush is an adventure action typing videogame about the phenomenon that happened in California in 1849. Jerrod Wilson, the protagonist, cut off his rutine in search of gold to get rich and shed some light about the location of his brother. 

GAMEPLAY:
You move your character with the arrow keys and interact with your surroundings typing actions. For example: "Buy ticket", "Look","Use key" and "Open door". That's it.

MY PERSONAL OPINION:
I've played on and off this game, made a decent progress and now that I've found that I lost because I didn't do something earlier in the game, I just gave up. Not in the mood to do all of it over again as a machine. The game is interesting and can be tricky to get around on knowing what to do next, where to go. I had to resort to a guide because I couldn't get a verb right. I knew what to do in that situation, but didn't knew how to tell the game. Very frustrating. But overall, this kind of games can be fun because of their depth. A thing that didn't sound very important can have you lost the game. 

VERDICT:
I can recommend this game to people that enjoy old school games, curious people that want to experience what this game felt like and adventure lover players. Beware though, this game can be hard. Patience is with these games, key. Good luck and thank you for reading!

review:
"Gold Rush! Classic" jest działającą na aktualnych systemach (nie wiem czy zmienianą względem oryginału czy nie) wersją gry z 1988 roku. Wcielamy się tutaj w mężczyznę, który jak można się domyślić po tytule bierze udział w kalifornijskiej gorączce złota. Przyjemna, pixelowa grafika i tak charakterystyczne dla gier z tego okresu efekty dźwiękowe cieszą oczy i uszy podczas stosunkowo krótkiej, ale wymagającej rozgrywki. Do dyspozycji mamy trzy zupełnie różne drogi, które sprawiają, że grę można przechodzić kilkukrotnie i za każdym razem odkryć coś nowego.

Tym, co niestety sprawiło mi sporo problemów było sterowanie. Za wyjątkiem poruszania się, które wykonujemy strzałkami, żeby podjąć jakąkolwiek akcję należy wpisać odpowiednią komendę do znajdującej się pod samym ekranem gry konsoli. Komendy wpisujemy w języku angielskim i brzmią one na przykład "look book" czy "take photo". Niestety muszą one być dość specyficzne przez co nie zawsze działają jeśli sformułujemy polecenie nieco inaczej, niż zakłada to gra. 

Przez to, że bohater porusza się raczej powoli gracz niekoniecznie ma ochotę stosować metodę prób i błędów w obawie przed koniecznością błąkania się w żółwim tempie po kolejnych lokacjach. Szczerze powiedziawszy w pewnym momencie posiłkowałam się instrukcją przejścia gry i zostałam z nią już do końca. Tak, przyznaję się bez bicia że przechodziłam tę grę zerkając co chwilę na rozpiskę kolejnych czynności, które należy wykonać. I szczerze powiedziawszy nie żałuję, bo bez niej pewnie dość szybko bym sobie odpuściła. 

Zapewne sytuacja wygląda trochę inaczej jeśli ktoś ma do tej gry sentyment, może jeśli przechodził ją wiele lat temu. Ja niestety dostałam ją w swoje ręce dopiero teraz i ciężko byłoby mi polecić ją komukolwiek, kto nie jest zapaleńcem gatunku. Nie mogę też jednak stwierdzić, że nie bawiłam się przy niej dobrze. Przy odpowiedniej pomocy z zewnątrz daje ona sporo frajdy wynikającej głównie z poznawania historii bohatera oraz samego sterowania nim, niż z rozwiązywania zagadki tego, jaki ma być jego następny ruch.

review:
TLDR: A true classic adventure game with replay value! If you haven't tried it, you are missing out.

  I played Gold Rush! years ago when it was on old floppy disks so I was thrilled to find it available for download on Steam. The puzzles are fun and the classic artwork is beautifully detailed and designed for its era. There are some confusing moments when its hard to figure out what to do next, specifically in the very start, but normally the game tells you the situation and as long as you pay attention to the conversations and text you should be able to tell what needs to be done. The music is a truly classic sound. The beeps playing 'Oh! Susanna' in the start hit me right in the nostalgia bone from days of EGA adventure games like Space Quest and Police Quest.
  One thing this game had over its contemporaries was replayability. Unlike most adventure games which give you a very linear method of completion, this game gives you three different methods to travel to California. You can choose the overland method which gives you a feeling like being on the Oregon Trail, the Panama method which is a jungle adventure, and the Cape Horn method which gives you an adventure on the sea. Each one has different challanges to overcome and each one is well designed and fun.

  The biggest issue with this game is that it has the one thing that made Sierra games frustrating, NO BACKTRACKING! Basically there are items in the game which are acquired early on which are required near the end. If you forget to grab them or didn't even know you needed that item then you are going to have to restore back to a save point when you could get the item and play through everything all over again.
  A more minor issue is that you need to type in all your commands. This could be spun as a motivator to learn how to properly spell and type but for some people I could see how they would find it more cumbersome.

  In finale, a truly nostalgic look at the beginnings of gaming which still holds its own today. This is a definite recommend to all adventure gamers.

[u][h1]Summary:[/h1][/u]
This is my alltime favourite Sierra AGI game

[u][h1]The Good:[/h1][/u]
The feeling of freedom, actually believing that you could basicly do anything. Pick the route myself to California. There storyline held all to the end, the graphics are the best I have seen when it compared to other games developed with the Sierra adventure game interpretor.

[u][h1]The Bad:[/h1][/u]
The nasty disk error that i got when taking the boat to the West. Has nothing much to do with the game tho, more on how I treated my floppies in the 80s.

[u][h1]The Bottom Line:[/h1][/u]
Is you liked the other Sierra games with the text input (Larry 1, Space Quest 1,2 etc) you'r gonna love this one. The puzzles and the adventure in this game kicks ass, I had more fun with this when I first played that I have with Quake 3 today.

review:
You may want pass on Gold Rush for better games of the era if you have a choice. Sierra isn't known for Gold Rush and this adventure is on par with average adventure games of the day: needlessly difficult and unfair with few clues and punishment for trying your own solutions. I won't get into the many problems you'll encounter with this game design, but players will discover many of them within the first 15 minutes of starting the game.

Aside from the average game design, the music is beyond minimal and the graphics are in low resolution EGA. To make matters worse, the artist has an unfortunate propensity for very bright color selection, and, as of the version being reviewed, the graphics are poorly rendered by Dosbox 0.74, a 7 year old emulator. This simply does not look good on modern displays and is unacceptable.

review: This is probably one of the most obscure adventure games from Sierra's heyday, but it is definitely a cult classic. It has some of the usual contrivances of the early Sierra adventure games, like a bit too much trial and error in the beginning parts, a few random deaths, and maybe a somewhat illogical puzzle or two. However, the game really shines with its deep historical detail, great atmosphere, and interesting story. I would describe it as one part classic SCI Sierra game and one part Oregon Trail. It is worth a try if you have the patience for some of the annoying parts.

review:
Classic Sierra Adventure Games;

So, that intro from the beginning makes me *sigh* from the inside.  These games (for me) are memories of growing up and sitting on my father's knee and learning about computers...(the next step involved constructing my own PC from scratch, but that's a different story for a different time) 
Sierra INVENTED the adventure genre as far as I'm concerned, and "Gold Rush" is not only an excellent example of a classic adventure game, it is also the benchmark for self-involved concepts as well as being true to life history.
What I personally love about this game is remembering my youth (I was 8 when it came out) but what makes it spectacular for its development at the time is that not only is it an emotionally involved storyline (regarding the family story) it also sticks to factual history.  In addition it reminds me of the current housing crisis, in that if you don't sell your house before a certain set time in the game (always save, save, SAVE with these classics!) you lose a large amount of monies and can not proceed in the game as desired!!!
*LOL* These games always frustrated me when I was younger due to the fact that you almost EVERY TIME (with Sierra...<3 Sierra <3) had to RESTART a game from scratch if you missed ONE...MINISCULE...ITEM!!
But seriously, that's more realistic than ANY game I've seen or played up until now.  When else (In Real Life IRL) have you been able to rewind and make sure you did something in a specific way to ensure that things turned out the way you wanted?  In addition, when we played these games, if we were stuck, we couldn't just hop onto Google and figure out the answer, we had to call a hotline and pay REAL CASH to get a hint book that didn't always guarantee a correct answer, but still left us guessing...damn, love you Google, but seriously, you made life too easy!

*Steps off of soap box*

If you have a LITERAL dollar to spend, give Sierra adventuring a try.  King's Quest (which I KNOW you've heard of) Space Quest (in my opinion better than King's Quest) Quest For Glory (Best. Game. Series. EVER. end of story)  Leisure Suit Larry (good for all of persons out there as dirty in the mind as I am) and so many, many more!

Gold Rush remains a classic to me, please enjoy it with me.

Продукт эпохи первых квестов от "Sierra Entertainment". Текстовое управление с визуальным рядом которое всегда с трудностью давалось русскоязычным пользователям. Игра не была хитом и прошла мимо меня во времена прохождения других известных проектов компании. Сейчас все выглядит морально устаревшим. Управление современным игрокам покажется крайне сложным и непонятным, а графика конца восьмидесятых сможет отпугнуть даже самых стойких. Все бы ничего, но пару лет назад вышел ремейк игры с полностью перерисованной графикой и упрощённым управлением, с возможностью играть в классическом варианте. Почему классическую игру до сих пор продают? Непонятно... Считаю, что она должна подаваться бесплатно к ремейку и никак иначе. Переходите сразу к ремейку:
http://store.steampowered.com/app/319230/

[h1]Оценка: Нет[/h1]

[h1]Послесловие:[/h1]
Если вам понравился этот обзор добро пожаловать в группу
http://steamcommunity.com/groups/uojer - тут вы сможете увидеть рекомендованные мною игры, другие обзоры, а также просто пообщаться в хорошей компании.

review:
[h1]Gold Rush! Classic - Uma Jornada Épica pelo Ouro na Califórnia de 1849[/h1]

Introdução:
Em uma imersão profunda no ano de 1849, onde o ouro cintilava nas terras da Califórnia, Gold Rush! Classic ressuscita uma das eras mais emocionantes da história americana. Neste jogo, somos transportados para um período de descobertas e desafios, onde a febre do ouro instiga aventureiros a percorrerem distâncias épicas em busca da riqueza reluzente.

Narrativa Épica:
Gold Rush! Classic nos leva a vivenciar as três rotas que dezenas de milhares de destemidos exploradores trilharam em direção às regiões auríferas. Encarnando Jerrod Wilson, mergulhamos nas experiências únicas de cada jornada, cada trilha marcada pela promessa de fortuna e pela incerteza do desconhecido.

Exploração e Desafios:
Como Jerrod Wilson, enfrentamos os rigores da natureza selvagem, superando desafios que incluem desde a travessia de rios revoltos até confrontos com outros aventureiros em busca do precioso ouro. Cada passo é uma batalha contra o terreno acidentado, a escassez de recursos e a pressão do tempo, enquanto tentamos esculpir nosso destino nas margens do Rio Sacramento.

Vivenciando a História:
Gold Rush! Classic não é apenas um jogo; é uma cápsula do tempo que nos permite experimentar a vida durante a corrida do ouro, com detalhes meticulosos que transportam os jogadores para a atmosfera autêntica da Califórnia de 1849. A trilha sonora envolvente e os gráficos imersivos amplificam a sensação de estar realmente lá, forjando o próprio destino em meio ao fervor do ouro.

Recomendação:
Para os aventureiros de coração intrépido e aqueles que anseiam por uma jornada no tempo, Gold Rush! Classic é uma experiência imperdível. Este jogo não apenas oferece entretenimento, mas também mergulha nas profundezas da história americana, transportando-nos para uma época repleta de esperança, desafios e a busca incessante por riquezas. Seja você um entusiasta de história, estrategista nato ou simplesmente alguém em busca de uma narrativa envolvente, Gold Rush! Classic promete uma jornada épica, onde cada decisão molda seu destino em meio à febre do ouro. Prepare-se para desbravar as trilhas empoeiradas e descobrir se você tem o que é preciso para triunfar na corrida do ouro de 1849. Aventure-se, descubra e deixe sua marca na história dourada da Califórnia!

review:
Gold Rush è un gioco punta-e-clicca del 1988 ambientato nella prima metà dell'800. In termini videoludici si tratta di un'era geologica fa, è indubbio però lo spessore della trama del gioco (impersoniamo un giornalista che si ritrova nel bel mezzo della scoperta dell'oro in California) e l'ottima resa dell'ambientazione (le malattie potrebbero portarci alla morte, cosa rara in un punta-e-clicca).
Forse non è un gioco da 2016, in alcuni punti infatti il gioco può apparire frustrante. La software house Sierra, a quei tempi, non regalava niente ai propri giocatori e ogni piccolo passo che facevi te lo dovevi guadagnare usando la materia grigia. 
Unica pecca: mi aspettavo una localizzazione del gioco in più lingue rispetto a quella originale (inglese).


Voto: 6.5/10.

review:
Thrilled to have picked up a copy of Gold Rush! This gem was one that took a lot of perseverance from my part to finish all possible paths, back then. There are multiple ways to complete the game, which is something that was unusual for the time, and it truly provided me with numerous hours of fun. It was also possible to progress in your adventure only to find later that you'd failed to buy a vital piece of equipment from the hardware store :) So save, try, load, try again, save.

Produced by Sierra, which was then becoming a household name in these kind of titles, this is the product of an age when games relied on actual story and not on graphics. Recommended.

Travel from New York to California as Jerrod Wilson during the Great Gold Rush of 1849 & strike it rich while visiting 3 different locations along the way but each route has its dangers since Sierra Adventure Games are known for is that fact that you can die in adventure games if you're careless with your actions or via random deaths.

Don't take TOO LONG to leave NY In-Game, otherwise passages to California increase in price since the game is timed.

review:
Wow is this a Flashback to the old apple computer days.
Wow, I'll be the first to admit, this game is quite old and has aged a bit, I have yet to play the remake, and have played this before once a VERY long time ago but honestly don't remember much of it, But am writing this review strictly on the Steam Version.

The intro has a nice jaunty tune, And a story to get you into it before you even take control. It was put together very well, Then comes in Oh Susanna!, And it makes you feel even more like you in the goldrush days.
For as old as this is, the Graphics are actually not as bad as you'd think.
While they do like some advanced User in Paint was getting down, they still have a nice charm to them.

Unfortunently the music stops after the games starts and it becomes very queit 
Even talking to people doesn't make a sound

The Guy moves very slow, luckily there is an option in the menu, I quickly switched that to fastest so I can game on.

The controls arent bad, the response system is a little hard if your unfamiliar with games that garner your text responses.

The game is similiar to that of Monkey Island, another classic I might add.

The constant guessing is a double edge sword, while it is fun to guess, after awhile it can get a little annoying.

I was able to buy some stuff at the store, I found 2 places to buy tickets, but both have outrageous prices, I went to ask my boss for a raise, but just like real life he played dumb like he didn't know what I was talking about -_-

Then I got stopped by the police For being on Grass...Also Like Real life..
I Found my dead parents, Game is cool, just not easy without multiple choice.

Gotta admit the game is realistic tho lol.

Overall the Game is fun, But requires a lot of patience and a thinking mind.

PROS:
-----------------------------------------------
+Nostaligia
+Adventerous
+Great Music in intro

CONS:
-----------------------------------------------
-Movement Speed is Incredibly slow on default
-Not That Exciting
-Can become frustrating if you don't know what to type
-No music during most of gameplay

review:
This is an oft overlooked classic, and deserves a play.  Designed on Sierra's AGI platform, players familiar with the original King's Quest, Space Quest, and Leisure Suit Larry games from the 80s will feel right at home.  The game offers replayability, as there are three different paths from Brooklyn to Sacramento, each with its own unique challenges and puzzles to overcome.  The designers also painstakingly went to great lengths to include various points of historical detail about The United States as it was being formed, and the sacrifices made and hardships endured by those who risked the journey across... granted, it's a work of pure fiction, but it paints a believable picture, at least believable enough for an 80s adventure game to be immersive.

Well worth a play for the price.

Play this game and have a taste of how games were back in the eighties!

review:
Tags : Adventure - P&C - Point and Click
Additional Tags: Delete Local Content & Remove from Library

TLDR: Very early era word parser adventure game. Very niche and easily outcompeted. Has been given a graphical remake since

Think original king quest featuring a boring somewhat modern era world and a guy in a suit.

Gold Rush Anniversary! Released by the same developers promised to bring this to a new audience, but was met with mixed reviews. The original will be great for potential nostalgia in some, but for most it is best avoided due to the cryptic nature of word parsers. 

Word parsers are a relic from the time where no graphical sprites were available. People would navigate simple mazes decribed in text paragraphs and attempt to use verbs at the paragraph to unlock progression.

This game routinely goes on sale for next to nothing, but I believe that whatever value is left to this game is in its atmosphere and perhaps the story and those things do not require you to play the actual game for best enjoyment.
https://store.steampowered.com/app/319230/Gold_Rush_Anniversary/

As a measure of comparison this is probably one of the lowest quality point&click adventure you could find. Made in Adventure Game studio by a couple of guys in their spare time and it is so much more playable than Gold Rush! In fact it is probably the closest direct improvement, also being set in modern era and having a point&click interface and a few nice puzzle designs for a similar price bracket.
https://store.steampowered.com/app/37400/Time_Gentlemen_Please_and_Ben_There_Dan_That_Special_Edition__Double_Pack/

review: This game can be super annoying if you don’t know what to expect.  Part of it is the primitive mechanics.  It’s not like today’s point and click game where you click on a location and the character will move there.  You have to use your arrow keys to direct every step of the movement.  You also have to instruct the character what to do.  Encountering another character will not automatically trigger conversation.  You have to tell your character to ‘talk’ by typing this in.  If you don’t type in the correct series of words, this will also halt your progress.  And last but not least, there is potential to fall into a big hole in this game.  Let’s say you did not pick up a certain something on level one, well if you don’t have it at level 10, you can forget finishing this game …   Still, there is a lot of charm to this game with its graphics and story plot.  I recommend it on sale.  I would also like to play the updated anniversary edition.

review: Gosh, growning up and getting my first 286 machine with a mathco and discovering the plethora of adventure games from Sierra On-line (then just Sierra), oh my old 2400 baud modem, my Game Blaster, oh and my CAD digitizer (I know I am geeking out here), but all of it made playing games like this so much fun and challenge.  Save often friends, you may live or you may die, but at least you can retry ;).  Gold Rush had to be one of the most entertaining games I played, I was a history buff and getting to somewhat live it in this game made it a true blast, and that is only part of the fun.  You also had to figure out what to say and how to say it correctly to get items, or get the correct information, or not die from scurvy going around the cape!  Everyone shoudl play this if nothing but for the history of adventure games.  Thank you for reading!

author: {'steamid': '76561198001026871', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 604, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 275, 'last_played': 1447326442}
review:
This was one of the classic early Sierra adventure games, featuring random deaths, the ever-present threat of mining the wrong claim, and proof of Al Lowe's sacred mantra 'Save Early, Save Often.' If you can get past the parser interface (you'll have to actually type with correct spelling with the approved verbs) this version seems to have fixed some of the timing issues (particularly the 'normal is timestop') in previous DosBox versions. It's fairly historically accurate, it's more than entertaining for a really old game, and for an old Sierra fan like myself, it was an instabuy.

The sound does seem to lag the game just a bit, which is odd. 

9/10
